marketNews.title: RI-EU Trade Agreement Near Completion
marketNews.content:
Indonesia and the European Union announced last weekend that both parties have reached a political agreement on a free trade agreement called the Comprehensive Economic Partnership Agreement (CEPA). Investment Minister Rosan Roeslani said on Monday (14 July) that the agreement, which has been negotiated for ten years, will be signed in September 2025.

So far, the details of the CEPA have not been disclosed. However, Coordinating Minister for Economic Affairs Airlangga Hartarto said in June 2025 that the agreement will give Indonesia zero tariffs for almost 80% of its export products to the EU together with the removal of other non-tariff barriers.

Airlangga added that the deal will give Indonesian export commodities to the EU a level playing field comparable to other Southeast Asian countries such as Thailand and Vietnam, which have historically enjoyed lower EU tariffs. He explained that Indonesian exports have been subject to tariffs of about 10-20% by the EU. According to various media, the commodities that face EU tariffs include palm-oil derivatives with rates of about 5-12.8%, biodiesel (palm-oil based) around 8-18%, textiles about 8-12%, and seafood around 16-20%.

Director General at the Ministry of Trade Djatmiko Bris Witjaksono said in June 2025 that the EU has committed to providing market access for priority Indonesian products such as palm oil, textiles, footwear, and seafood. In return, Indonesia has pledged to improve market access for EU agricultural and manufacturing products. Based on Djatmiko’s presentation slides, the main benefits for Indonesia include increased foreign direct investment from the EU in sectors such as renewable energy, semiconductors, and mineral derivatives.

In June 2025, Reuters reported that the CEPA would increase Indonesia’s exports to the EU by 5.4% according to an internal government benefit analysis, but senior Economic Minister Airlangga Hartarto said this was a conservative estimate and he targets a 50% increase in export volumes within three to four years after the agreement is implemented.

The EU is Indonesia’s fifth-largest trading partner, with total bilateral trade reaching €27.3 billion in 2024. Of that, Indonesia exported commodities worth €17.5 billion to the EU in 2024, while the EU exported commodities worth €9.7 billion to Indonesia.

The free trade agreement comes after the EU classified Indonesia as a ‘standard-risk’ country under its anti-deforestation law, meaning Indonesian exporters will be exempt from the strictest compliance checks for goods exported to Europe as of 30 December 2025. The agreement also appears amid trade tensions between the EU and the United States, where the EU is considering imposing tariffs on US products following President Donald Trump’s threat to levy a 30% tariff on most EU imports starting 1 August 2025.

marketNews.title: Key Takeaway
marketNews.content:
Overall, we assess that tariff and/or trade policies from President Donald Trump could increase the urgency for Indonesia and the EU to finalize this agreement as an alternative market for both parties.

Sectorally, we see that the significance of this trade deal for Indonesia lies in the textile and textile product (TPT) sector. According to estimates from the Indonesian Textile Association, TPT exports to Europe could grow up to 2-3 times within the next five years after the agreement is reached. This increase corresponds to about 15-30% of Indonesia’s total annual TPT exports, potentially revitalizing a sector that employs many workers in Indonesia. In contrast, for palm-oil and seafood products, the contribution of increased demand to total exports is relatively limited, given that the EU is not a primary market for these Indonesian exports.

marketNews.title: Hot News 1: Trump says firing Powell unlikely
marketNews.content: U.S. President Donald Trump on Wednesday (16 July) denied reports that he was seeking to remove Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell. Trump added that although the likelihood of removing Powell is very small, Powell could step down if he becomes involved in a fraud case. The statement indicates that the potential dismissal of Powell remains possible if strong reasons arise. Trump and his allies have recently criticized Powell over the cost of renovating the Federal Reserve’s headquarters in Washington, as well as the Fed’s decision to keep interest rates unchanged. Bloomberg reported that Trump’s remarks came after a White House official and several U.S. Congress members met with Trump on Tuesday (15 July) and said they expected Trump would take action against Powell.

marketNews.title: Hot News 2: Indonesia continues negotiations with US on tariffs, jets, minerals
marketNews.content: President-candidate Prabowo Subianto’s advisor and member of the National Economic Council, Mari Elka Pangestu, told Bloomberg that Indonesia will continue negotiations with the United States regarding sectoral tariffs, Boeing aircraft purchases, and critical minerals after securing a 19% tariff. Pangestu explained that Indonesia will give the U.S. broader access to exports that do not directly compete with Indonesian products, such as wheat and cotton. She added that she expects the impact of this access on Indonesia’s overall imports to be moderate. Pangestu said that a tariff agreement with the U.S. would benefit Indonesia as lower tariffs would apply to major Indonesian exports to the U.S., such as palm oil.

marketNews.title: Hot News 3: India seeks lower tariff than Indonesia in US trade deal
marketNews.content: Bloomberg reported that the Indian government is targeting lower tariffs than Indonesia and Vietnam in a trade deal with the United States. Indonesia and Vietnam currently face tariffs of 19% and 20% respectively from the U.S. State Bank of India chief economist Soumya Kanti Ghosh said India hopes the U.S. can reduce tariffs for its country to below 10%. Previously, President Donald Trump said that tariffs for India would not differ much from those imposed on Indonesia.

marketNews.title: Hot News 4: Investment realization reaches 475 trillion rupiah in 2Q25
marketNews.content: Vice Minister of Investment and Downstreaming, Todotua Pasaribu, said on Wednesday (16 July) that Indonesia’s investment realization in 2Q25 reached 475 trillion rupiah (up 10.9% year-on-year, up 2.2% quarter-on-quarter). This result brings total investment realization for 1H25 to 940 trillion rupiah (up 13.3% year-on-year), equal to about 49.5% of the 2025 target of 1,900 trillion rupiah.

tickerNews.title: TPIA re-enters SSIA shareholder list
tickerNews.content: Chandra Asri Pacific ($TPIA) is recorded as holding approximately 284.8 million shares (6.05%) of Surya Semesta Internusa ($SSIA) through the Individual Customer Fund managed by Henan Putihrai Asset Management (PDNI HPAM – CAP Fund). This transaction is only recorded in KSEI data as of 15 July 2025, so the transaction value is unknown. Previously, TPIA appeared in the shareholder list with ownership above 5% in SSIA in March 2025, before disappearing from the list. In April 2025, TPIA Director Suryandi told Katadata that the fund was intended for a portfolio instrument, not to acquire SSIA shares. In addition, KSEI data as of 15 July 2025 shows that Djarum-group affiliated entity PT Dwimuria Investama Andalan increased its SSIA holdings by about 2.6 million shares, raising its ownership from 5.83% to 5.89%.

tickerNews.title: BNGA credit growth reported
tickerNews.content: The President Director of Bank CIMB Niaga, Lani Darmawan, told Investor Daily that the bank recorded credit growth of +6.8% year-on-year during the first half of 2025, compared with +8.7% YoY in 1Q25 and +5.9% YoY in 1H24, in line with the 2025 guidance of 5-7% YoY.

tickerNews.title: ASRI reports 2Q25 marketing sales
tickerNews.content: Alam Sutera Realty reported marketing sales of 646 billion rupiah in 2Q25 (up 3% YoY, down 13% QoQ). This result brings 1H25 marketing sales to 1.4 trillion rupiah (up 17% YoY), equal to 40% of the 2025 target of 3.5 trillion rupiah. The residential segment contributed 72% of 1H25 marketing sales, consisting of house sales (69%) and apartments (3%). The remaining 28% came from commercial segment sales, mainly commercial land sales. Marketing sales from other property issuers can be read in the Snips compilation.

tickerNews.title: NSSS director purchases shares
tickerNews.content: The President Director of Nusantara Sawit Sejahtera, Teguh Patriawan, bought approximately 36.8 million NSSS shares at an average price of 300 rupiah per share on 14 July 2025. The total transaction value was about 11 billion rupiah. After this transaction, Patriawan’s direct ownership in NSSS rose from 10.84% to 11%.

tickerNews.title: PYFA acquisition strategy and global steps
tickerNews.content: PYFA’s acquisition strategy: 'Acquiring Probiotec Limited makes the PYFA group recognized as a global player, and even now many are lining up to cooperate in the new factory that has been operating in Q2 2025.'
